page.title: 12Birds on the Moor
page.content: In our travels around the area several birds have been seen. Possibly the most common is the {Skylark.}In the summer months its song enlivens the atmosphere of the moor. It seems as if one is not alone with the sound of the Skylark shimmering down from a cloudless blue sky. Another common bird seen on the moor is the{Wheatear.}This bird is distictive in that it has a bright white rump. Rumour has it that the bird used to be called "whitearse", but this was changed to Wheatear to suit out choosy Victorian ancestors. {Crows}are common on the moor, but if you are lucky you will see a{raven feeding on the lambs that do not make it. This large black bird is easy to recognise by its size. Finally there is the king of the moorbirds,- the{Buzzard.
